engine

Class World

  • java.lang.Object
    • javafx.scene.Node
      • javafx.scene.Parent
        • javafx.scene.layout.Region
          • javafx.scene.layout.Pane
            • engine.World
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    javafx.css.Styleable, javafx.event.EventTarget

    public abstract class World
extends javafx.scene.layout.Pane

    A World is an extension of a Pane that holds Actor objects (Actor extends ImageView). Since a World extends Pane, it already keeps track of its children Nodes for you. You will implement a custom method getObjects(cls) that returns a list of children of type cls. To implement that method, you will need to call getChildren() so you can loop through and filter the list of children to get a list of only the children of type cls. In all other cases, you should use the getObjects(cls) method to access children, so you can get a list of only the types of children you want to process.

    To add actors to the world you should use the add(Actor actor) method.

    A World contains the following private attributes:

    • An AnimationTimer that calls act() on the world and on each actor in the world every frame.
    • A variable that keeps track of whether the timer is running.
    • A Set of KeyCode objects that holds all the keys that are currently being pressed.
    • Variable(s) that keep track of whether the width and height have been set. Since width and height of Nodes is always 0 until layout is done (some time after show() is called on the stage), you will need a way to determine when the World has been given a real width and height so you can use the getWidth() and getHeight() methods when positioning your actors.
    Author:
    Ted_McLeod

    • Constructor Detail

      • World

        public World()

        Creates a instance of a World. In the World constructor you will need to do some initialization:

        • Initialize the variable(s) you will use to keep track of whether the dimensions of the world have been set.
        • Initialize the set of keys that are currently pressed
        • Initialize the variable keeping track of whether the timer is running.
        • Add a listener to the widthProperty() so you will know when the width has changed from zero to a valid width
          • When the value first changes to a valid width, you should update your instance variable(s) accordingly
          • If both width and height have been set, you should call the onDimensionsInitialized() method
        • Add a listener to the heightProperty() so you will know when the height has changed from zero to a valid height
          • When the value first changes to a valid height, you should update your instance variable(s) accordingly
          • If both width and height have been set, you should call the onDimensionsInitialized() method
        • Note: It is critical that onDimensionsInitialized() is called exactly ONCE, when BOTH width AND height have been initialized during layout of the stage.
        • Add a listener to the sceneProperty(). If the new scene is not null, then the world was added to a scene so it should request focus so it can receive key events.
        • setOnKeyPressed to add the KeyCode to the Set of keys that are pressed. You can use a private inner class, anonymous inner class or lambda expression.
        • setOnKeyReleased to remove the KeyCode from the Set of keys that are pressed. You can use a private inner class, anonymous inner class or lambda expression.
        • Initialize an AnimationTimer object. You can use an anonymous inner class, lambda expression or a private inner class that extends AnimationTimer.
          • Inside the handle() method, call act() on this world and on each actor in the world.
          • Warning: Before calling act() on an actor, you should confirm it is still in the world.

    • Method Detail

      • start

        public void start()
        STARTS the timer that calls the act method on the world and on each Actor in the world each frame.

      • stop

        public void stop()
        STOPS the timer that calls the act method on the world and on each Actor in the world each frame.

      • isStopped

        public boolean isStopped()
        Returns whether or not the world's timer is stopped
        Returns:
        true if the timer is stopped and false otherwise

      • add

        public void add(Actor actor)

        Adds the given actor to the world and then calls the addedToWorld() method on the actor that was added.

        Note: Since the world is a Pane, you should get the list of children and add the actor to that list.

        Parameters:
        actor - the actor to add.

      • remove

        public void remove(Actor actor)

        Removes the given actor from the world.

        Note: Since the world is a Pane, you should get the list of children and remove the actor from that list.

        Parameters:
        actor - The actor to remove.

      • getObjects

        public <A extends Actor> java.util.List<A> getObjects(java.lang.Class<A> cls)
        Returns a list of all the actors in the world of the given class.
        • The method header is given to you already so just copy it as is. Here is an explanation:
          • <A extends Actor> is saying the type parameter A must be either an Actor or a subclass of Actor.
          • Class is a class that models a class. It has useful methods for finding out information about a class, such as which methods or fields it has or if an object is an instance of the class or a subclass.
            • You can get a Class object by writing ClassName.class or by calling getClass() on an object.
            • The type parameter A is the class represented by the Class object. For example, Actor.class is a Class<Actor> and Ball.class is a Class<Ball>.
            • Since the same type parameter A is used in the parameter Class<A> cls and the return type List<A>, then the A in List<A> will be the same type as the A in the parameter cls. Thus, getObjects(Ball.class) will return a List<Ball>. If Ball was not a sublass of Actor, then getObjects(Ball.class) would throw a compiler error.
        • Implementation details:
          • Create an empty list to hold objects of type A
          • Loop through the list of children in the world and for each child, if the child is an instance of the class represented by cls, then add it to the list you created. At the end, you should return the list you created.
          • Useful methods in java.lang.Class:

            • boolean isInstance(Object obj) returns true if obj is an instance of the class modeled by this Class object or a subclass of that class.

              Example: if Class<Ball> b is set to Ball.class, then b.isInstance(obj) would return true if and only if obj was an instance of Ball or a subclass of Ball.

            • T cast(Object obj) returns a reference to obj type casted to the type modeled by this Class object.

              Example: if Class<Ball> b = Ball.class, then b.cast(obj) would be equivalent to type casting obj to a Ball, as in (Ball) obj.

        Type Parameters:
        A - the type of actors returned in the list (will also be the class represented by cls)
        Parameters:
        cls - The Class object representing the type of actor that will be in the list. To get all actors, pass Actor.class
        Returns:
        a list of all the actors in the world of the given class.

      • getObjectsAt

        public <A extends Actor> java.util.List<A> getObjectsAt(double x,
                                                        double y,
                                                        java.lang.Class<A> cls)
        Returns a list of all actors of the given class containing the given x, y
        Type Parameters:
        A - the type of actors returns in the list (will also be the class represented by cls)
        Parameters:
        x - the x value of the contained point
        y - the y values of the contained point
        cls - The Class object representing the type of actor that must contain the point. To include all actors that contain the point, pass Actor.class
        Returns:
        a list of Actors of the given class that contain the given point

      • isKeyPressed

        public boolean isKeyPressed(javafx.scene.input.KeyCode code)
        Returns true if the given key is pressed and false otherwise.
        Parameters:
        code - The KeyCode for the key that is being checked
        Returns:
        true if the given key is currently pressed and false otherwise.

      • onDimensionsInitialized

        public abstract void onDimensionsInitialized()
        Subclasses should override this. This method is called after the world width and height have been initialized. This method would be a good place to add actors to your world because getWidth() and getHeight() will return the real dimensions of the world instead of 0.

      • act

        public abstract void act(long now)
        This method is called every frame once start has been called.
        Parameters:
        now - the current time in nanoseconds.
